q1.question:
One side at this battle found its only significant success through an assault on a baggage train
and was hindered by enemy palings. One side at this battle had previously besieged Harfleur. An
initial cavalry charge in this battle failed miserably and churned the field with mud, thus
impairing subsequent advances on foot by forces led by the Constable of France. For 10 points,
name this English victory for Henry V in the Hundred Years War thanks to the efficiency of
longbows.

Most members of this organization also participate in the Schengen [shane-gun] Area. This
organization, which guarantees the single market, grew out of an agreement between the “inner
six” to trade coal and steel. This winner of the 2012 Nobel Peace Prize was created by the Treaty
of Maastricht [mass-strict], but is currently threatened by the possible “Grexit.” For 10 points,
name this organization of 28 member states across a namesake continent.

This politician called Russia “a riddle, wrapped up in a mystery, inside an enigma.” The
failure of the Gallipoli Campaign tarnished the early career of this orator who capped off his best
speeches with phrases like “blood, toil, tears, and sweat” and “this was their finest hour.” Taking
office after Neville Chamberlain resigned, this politician led his country through the Battle of
Britain. For 10 points, name this Prime Minister who led Britain through most of World War II.

One of this king’s cabinet ministers was wounded at Putney Heath after a duel. He was
advised early in life by Lord Bute and married Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz [STRAYELits]. After this man refused to support Catholic Emancipation, his prime minister Pitt the
Younger resigned. Earlier in his reign, Pitt the Elder helped this king defeat France and Lord
North passed the Intolerable Acts. For 10 points, name this mad king who ruled during the
American Revolution.

The early Christian thinker Tertullian [turr-TOOL-ee-uhn] asked “what has (this city) to do
with Jerusalem?” The royal stoa [STOH-uh] of Attalos [uh-TALL-ohs] is found in this city.
Berlin’s Brandenburg Gate was copied from a large gate to a landmark in this city called the
Propylaea [pro-pull-AYE-uh]. The explosion of an Ottoman munitions dump damaged this city's
most famous landmark, from which a set of marble sculptures were removed by Lord Elgin. For
10 points, name this European capital city in which the Parthenon [PAR-thuh-nonn] can be
found on the Acropolis [uh-CROP-uh-luhs].

This ruler employed a physician who combated rampant paranoia about the undead in Moravia
and worked with the Count von Haugwitz to reform the empire. This employer of Gerard von
Swieten was consort to the Duke of Lorraine, Francis Stephen, and signed the Treaty of Breslau
to end the First Silesian War. The Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle [ex-luh-shuh-pell] ended a war
begun after this ruler's ascension, in violation of Salic Law, under the Pragmatic Sanction. For 10
points, name this Habsburg Queen who fought the War of the Austrian Succession.

This party controlled government during the Thirteen Wasted Years. It lost power in 1974
with the failure of leader Edward Heath, but regained it when its opponents suffered the “Winter
of Discontent.” In the 1980s, this party dealt with a miners’ strike in its efforts to weaken unions
and privatize state industries. For 10 points, name this British political party once led by
Margaret Thatcher, which opposes the Labour Party.

tossup.question:
The government that started this war was re-elected when Lord Salisbury triumphed in the
Khaki Election. This war was ended by the Treaty of Vereeniging [vur-EEN-uh-ging]. The raid
led by Leander Starr Jameson raised tensions before this war. It was sparked by the discovery of
gold in the Witwatersrand [wit-wut-urz-and]. For 10 points, name this war in which Great Britain
defeated Dutch-speaking South African farmers.

bonus.question:
The British used these facilities to house Boer civilians during the war, often with little
food. Later, worse examples include Buchenwald [boo-ken-vahld] and Dachau[dock-ow].

tossup.question:
One side in this battle landed at Pevensey, while the other had just resisted a Viking invasion
led by Harald Hardrada [hard-dra-duh] at Stamford Bridge. Feigned retreats lead to the thinning
of the shield wall at this battle, although the death of one commander was the deciding factor.
For 10 points, name this 1066 victory for William the Conqueror that lead to the Norman
conquest of England.

bonus.question:
The Battle of Hastings is recorded in this work of art, which depicts Harold Godwinson
being felled by an arrow to his eye.

tossup.question:
This region’s independence was sought by the outlawed Batasuna [bah-tah-soo-nah] party. Its
namesake mountain range is the eastern section of the Cantabrian Mountains. A city in this
region contains a Frank Gehry-designed Guggenheim Museum. For 10 points, Bilbao is in what
autonomous community of northern Spain whose native language is a linguistic isolate?

bonus.question:
Santiago de Compostela is the capital of which other northern Spanish autonomous
community, home to a language more closely related to Portuguese than Spanish?

tossup.question:
This leader refused to appear before the Council of Blood and backed the Watergeuzen [wuhtur-goy-zen]. He arranged for the signing of the Pacification of Ghent and the Union of Utrecht
to oppose the Duke of Parma. He started the Eighty Years’ War. For 10 points, name this Prince
of Orange from the House of Nassau, a rebel leader who declared the independence of the
Netherlands.

bonus.question:
Give the noble title or nickname of Fernando Alvarez de Toledo, who convened the
Council of Blood after being sent by Philip II to the Netherlands to crush dissent.

tossup.question:
This ruler repressed the “pride and folly” of Tassilo, the rebellious Duke of Bavaria, and
fought battles against the Avars that rendered Pannonia [pann-OH-nee-uh] an uninhabitable
wasteland. His court at Aachen [OCK-en] was the center of a domain that he passed on to his
son, Louis the Pious. For 10 points, name this Frankish king, a patron of learning who became
the first Holy Roman Emperor.

bonus.question:
The two major lives of Charlemagne were written by Notker [NOT-kurr] the
Stammerer and what courtier [COURT-eer] who studied at Charlemagne’s palace school?

tossup.question:
This country’s flag emerges from the “N” in the iconic blood-red logo of one of its protest
movements, which forced its government to agree to the Round Table Talks. This country’s
Gdansk [guh-DONSK] Shipyards were where an electrician founded the trade union Solidarity.
2015 NHB Set A
Bowl Round 1
For 10 points, name this Eastern European country whose largest city was headquarters to the
Warsaw Pact.

bonus.question: What electrician founded Solidarity and later became President of Poland?

tossup.question:
One politician from this country, Rena Dourou [door-ooh], was recently attacked on national
television. A January 2015 election here saw the center-right New Democracy lose power to the
left-wing Syriza [sur-ree-zuh] party, which ran on an anti-austerity platform. Its finance minister
recently secured a four-month bailout extension from the “troika.” [troy-kuh] For 10 points,
Alexis Tsipras [sip-priss] leads what indebted Eurozone country, whose capital is Athens?

bonus.question:
This allegedly Nazi right-wing party has the third most seats in Greece’s Parliament,
although it lost one seat in the January elections.

tossup.question:
An early battle in this conflict was the clash at Covadonga, which was a victory for the
Visigoth Pelayo. Its turning point is usually considered the defeat of the Almohads at the 13th
century Battle of Las Navas de Tolosa. The union of several factions in this conflict led to the
joint rule of the Dual Monarchs. El Cid was a heroic figure from, for 10 points, what conflict
concluded by Ferdinand and Isabella that ended the period of Islamic government in Spain?

bonus.question:
The end of the Reconquista is considered to be the surrender of Granada by this man, this
last Muslim ruler in Iberia.

tossup.question:
This woman aided Richard Harman, who was arrested for smuggling illegal Tyndale Bibles.
This woman’s influence is credited with causing the downfall of Lord Chancellor Thomas
Wolsey. Along with musician Mark Smeaton, this niece of Thomas Howard was imprisoned in
the Tower of London on charges of adultery. For 10 points, name this woman executed in 1536,
the second wife of Henry VIII.

bonus.question:
After Anne’s death her husband faced what Catholic rebellion based in Yorkshire and
led by Robert Aske?

q3.prompt: Before, during, and after D-Day, who or what was…

questions.question: The region of France that contains all five invasion beaches?
The operational code name of D-Day?
The most heavily defended beach on D-Day, named after the largest city in Nebraska?
The general, nicknamed “Desert Fox”, who commanded German forces at D-Day?
Oceanic term for the “wall” of German defenses along the French coast?
The British namesake of modified tanks known as “funnies” used during the invasion?

The US Army division nicknamed the “Screaming Eagles” who paradropped behind German
lines on D-Day?

City on the Orne River that was liberated by the Canadians on July 9th, more than a month
behind schedule?
Possibly ordered his mother’s assassination and ruled during the Great Fire of Rome?

Defeated Maxentius [max-ENN-shuss] at the Battle of the Milvian [MILL-vee-uhn] Bridge
and introduced Christianity to the Empire?
Was known for his insanity and attempting to make his horse a Consul?
Was the last of the Five Good Emperors and author of Meditations?
Ended the Crisis of the Third Century and created the Tetrarchy?
Succeeded his father Vespasian and was Emperor during the Vesuvius eruption?
Was captured in battle and made into a footstool by Sassanid King Shapur I?
Won the Battle of the Frigidus [“frigid”-uss] and was the last to rule over the entire Empire?

q3.prompt: During the War of Spanish Succession who or what…

questions.question: Was the “Sun King” of France?
Was the royal house which the French wanted on the Spanish throne?
Was the royal house which previously ruled Spain and also ruled Austria?
Was the king of Spain who died at the onset of the war, causing the succession crisis?
Was the English king during the war, a Dutch stadtholder who jointly ruled with Mary?
Was the preeminent English general of the war and ancestor of a later Prime Minister?
Was the 1704 British victory that names a palace in Oxfordshire?
Was the French nobleman who took the Spanish throne at the beginning of the war?

parts:
(30 pts) A king of this nation became known as “the desired” by his supporters after he and his
father were forced to abdicate at Bayonne and were replaced by Joseph (20 pts)

Bonaparte. The
ensuing invasion of this country was referred to as an “Ulcer” by Napoleon. The Duke of
Wellington defeated French forces in this nation with help from irregulars who launched a
“little war” that is the origin of the word (10 pts)

“guerrilla.” For 10 points, much of the fighting
during the Peninsular War occurred in what country that borders Portugal?

(30 pts) This group’s law code was named after its founder and required the election of a Rat, a
council led by four burgomeisters. This organization fought pirates called the Victual
Brothers and signed the Treaty of Stralsund with Valdemar IV. This organization
established the (20 pts)

London Steelyard as one of its kontores, or offices, which were also
found in Novgorod and Antwerp. This group’s members included its founding city of (10 pts)

Lubeck as well as Danzig and Hamburg. For 10 points, Baltic Sea commerce was once
dominated by what northern European trading league?

(30 pts) This conflict was called a “war without an enemy” by William Waller, who spent most of
it fighting against Hopton's Cornish army. Incidents in this war included the Battle of
Chalgrove Field, where John Hampden was fatally wounded, and the defense of Turnham
Green by the trained bands of (20 pts)

London. This war's outcome was decided at the Battle of
Naseby, where the “Oxford Army” was smashed by the (10 pts)

Roundhead cavalry of the New
Model Army. For 10 points, name this 17th century conflict in which the Long Parliament
defeated Stuart royalists.

(30 pts) This project was originally named BONIFACE to give the illusion that a well-placed spy
was responsible for the project. The addition of a fourth (20 pts)

rotor was a major setback for
this project. Under this project, Gordon Welchman invented the bombe [“bomb”] at
Bletchley Park with the help of (10 pts)

Alan Turing, and its success meant accurate tracking of Uboat movements. For 10 points, identify this project which allowed the Allies to read Axis
encrypted communications by deciphering a certain machine.

(30 pts) This man successfully negotiated his opponents’ evacuation of Chippenham in the
Treaty of Wedmore [WEDD-more]. This man, who translated the first English versions of
Pastoral Care and The (20 pts)

Consolation of Philosophy, was the subject of a biography by
Asser [ASS-urr]. This victor at Edington established the limits of the (10 pts)

Danelaw [DANElaw] by defeating Guthrum [GOOTH-rumm]. For 10 points, name this King of Wessex whose
erudition and successful defense against Vikings made him the first person known as “King of
England” and only one called “the Great.”

(30 pts) This country’s lore includes a “plain of joy” called Mag Mell, and a land of youth called
Tir na nog. One of this country’s culture heroes defends a brown bull from being stolen by
single-handedly engaging (20 pts)

Queen Medb’s [MAYV’s] warriors during the Cattle Raid of
Cooley. Another legendary hero of this country gained wisdom by tasting the (10 pts)

salmon of
knowledge. This country’s folk heroes include Cuchulain and Finn McCool. For 10 points, name
this country whose mythology is described in the Ulster Cycle, a manuscript of which is in its
city of Dublin.

(30 pts) One ruler from this kingdom led the “Long campaign” and was captured following a
defeat at the battle of Varna. The Black Army led by the son of that ruler successfully
besieged Vienna and engaged in many conflicts with the Ottomans. Besides (20 pts)

Janos
Hunyadi [hoon-yah-dee] and Matthias Corvinus [kore-vine-us], other leaders from the
Arpad dynasty here include its founder, (10 pts)

Stephen I. The Treaty of Trianon formally
abolished this kingdom, whose privileges were confirmed by the Ausgleich [oss-glike] of 1867.
For 10 points, name this Magyar kingdom later absorbed into a dual-monarchy with Austria.
